content.body: is there an js event for when an <audio> has finished playing?
wonders what possessed him to get into an argument about economics on Slashdot
AryehGregor: lol!
JonathanNeal, there's an ended event
JonathanNeal, see http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/video.html#mediaevents
http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/33280/xhtmlmod2010/results (Member-only)
hsivonen: that's not a lot of responses...
wow
I'm surprised dbaron didn't enter "other comments"
with interest like this, there's no need to make a point
i think that pretty much sums it up
I bet it still goes to REC
duh
if it didn't go to rec that would mean the w3c followed w3c process
I would love to see the implementation report they used to exit CR
are there any implementation criteria to meet?
othermaciej: seen the XLink 1.1 impl report?
I wonder what their exit criteria are
I wonder why they aren't cited in the AC survey
there isn't even a link to the spec in the survey
hsivonen, is it public?
secret
XLink is such a joke
it's extremely unfortunate it went into SVG
http://www.w3.org/XML/2006/01/xlink11-implementation
and MathML too, maybe?
isn't that it?
that's public
that doesn't appear to be Member-only
that's what the REC in TR links to
such a joke
SVG implementations only support XLink to the extent that they need to recognize certain attributes of XLink on certain elements
I believe according to the XLink guys that is valid usage of XLink...
I wonder if I should waste Dave Singer's time by asking him to vote no on any PR survey that doesn't cite the CR exit criteria and implementation report
apparently only specs that reality impiges on have to follow w3c process
why impose requirements on lalaland?
I usually tell him not to respond at all on stuff we don't care about
the level of double standard at the w3c is so astronomical it makes a joke of the whole thing
svg 1.2 tiny being my favourite example
to be fair, getting html5 right is orders of magnitude more important than getting xlink 1.1 right
if the w3c staff admitted that and justified ignoring process on the "unimportant" specs because of that, then i wouldn't feel like that was actually just a coincidence
I think no one is fussy about process until people complain, generally
otoh with svg 1.2 there were lots of complaints
so that's the one that seems like an outlier
i'm ptretty sure the xlink 1.1 iml report used to be secret
the xlink 1.1 CR exit criteria did include "There are at least two interoperable implementations of the specification."
of every feature?
the implementation report doesn't seem to give any evidence for that assertion
is there a test suite? i'd love to learn how xlink is supposed to actually work
http://www.w3.org/XML/2006/03/xlink11-tests
in what sense is that a test suite?
in the sense that it was linked from the implementation report in the section with a header of "Test Suite"
points back to his comment about the process being a joke half the time
I am having a hard time running those tests in my browser because they are served with a Content-type of "charset=utf-8"[sic]
also uses external entity references
if I load one by hand after downloading I get a blank page - not sure if that is a pass or fail
http://twitter.com/t/status/14075258381
tantek is so much ahead of us
so, the last version of XHTML Modularization 1.1 to link to an implementation report linked to this: http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/2006/m12n-11-implementation.html
the PER doesn't have a link to an impleentation report at all
http://blogs.msdn.com/ericlippert/archive/2010/04/12/ignoring-parentheses.aspx#comments <-- i guess microsoft really _doesn't_ care about interop with their .NET framework afterall, who knew
*feigned surprise*
seems like an issue with the C# language, not the .NET framework
yes
C# is part of .NET
anyway, I'm not that surprised that they ruled out changing the compiler, but I am surprised that they ruled out changing the spec
